channel.title: World News, News of World, Top World News, World Breaking Headlines - Times of India
channel.description: TOI delivers the Top Latest World news and Headlines from US, UK, Gulf, Pakistan, China, Europe and rest of the world.

image.title: World News, News of World, Top World News, World Breaking Headlines - Times of India

item.title: Saarc nations vow to combat terrorism, piracy
item.description: Saarc countries today vowed to combat common challenges of terrorism, piracy, human trafficking, drugs smuggling, cyber crime and corruption by forging cooperation among the law enforcement agencies of the eight-member grouping.

item.title: Anti-Islamic ads coming to New York transit system
item.description: Anti-Islamic advertisements will begin appearing on a hundred New York City buses and at two subway entrances next week.

item.title: Car bomb attacks kill 20 people in Baghdad
item.description: In the day's deadliest attack, a parked explosives-packed car detonated near the al-Mubarak mosque in central Baghdad's mostly

item.title: Obama anti-IS coalition takes shape as France joins war
item.description: France carried out its first air strike against the Islamic State group in Iraq on Fridat, boosting US-led efforts to unite the world against the growing threat posed by the jihadists.

item.title: Putin seeks power to 'unplug' Russia from internet
item.description: Moscow is considering measures to disconnect Russian cyberspace, the last forum for free expression in the country, in emergency situations such as military hostilities or major protests, a newspaper reported on Friday.

item.title: Pak court acquits PM, brother in money laundering case
item.description: A Pakistani court on Friday cleared Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and his brother, Punjab chief minister Shahbaz Sharif of all charges pertaining to a money laundering case filed 14 years ago.

item.title: Sierra Leone launches controversial Ebola shutdown
item.description: Sierra Leone on Friday launched a controversial three-day shutdown to contain the deadly spread of the Ebola virus, as the UN Security Council declared the deadly outbreak a threat to world peace.

item.title: Iran ‘Happy’ singers get suspended jail, lashes: Report
item.description: The sentences are suspended for three years, meaning that if any of the seven is found guilty of a similar offence, the punishment is then carried out.

item.title: Under new plan in Iraq, ISIS fight may fall to provinces
item.description: The strategy is an acknowledgment of the failure of the Shiite-dominated national security forces to operate effectively and fairly in Sunni regions.

item.title: US man commits suicide after killing 6 grandchildren, daughter
item.description: A once-convicted felon killed six of his grandchildren, including an infant, his adult daughter and himself in a shooting at the man's home in a small town in rural northern Florida, a sheriff said.

item.title: Floods shut down Philippine capital
item.description: Presidential spokeswoman Abigal Valte said that work in government offices in the capital and 15 other provinces has been suspended.

item.title: Islamic State plot in Australia raises questions
item.description: The Islamic State plot to carry out random beheadings in Sydney alleged by police is a simple and barbaric scheme that has shaken Australians. But terrorism experts on Friday questioned whether the ruthless movement had the capacity or inclination to sustain a terror campaign so far from the Middle East.

item.title: New ISI chief to be named soon: Report
item.description: The new chief of Pakistan's powerful spy agency ISI is likely to be named next week amid political turmoil in the coup-prone country, according to a media report.

item.title: Syrian rebel training may take 12 months: US
item.description: Moderate Syrian rebels, once made battle-ready by a US-led coalition, may be asked to help restore the border between Syria and Iraq that the Islamic State group militants have effectively wiped out.

item.title: Australian police: Raids thwarted beheading plot
item.description: Police today said they thwarted a plot to carry out beheadings in Australia by supporters of the radical Islamic State group.

item.title: UK Muslims appeal to IS seeking release of British hostage
item.description: Over 100 Muslim clerics, groups and individuals in the UK have made a united appeal to the Islamic State terror group to show mercy and release a British hostage under their captivity.

item.title: Thai junta chief 'sorry' for bikini remarks after Brit murder
item.description: Thailand's junta chief apologized on Wednesday for suggesting tourists in bikinis could be more vulnerable to attack, comments which caused an international outcry following the brutal murder of two British holidaymakers.

item.title: Death toll in Nigeria building collapse rises to 80: Rescuers
item.description: The death toll from a collapsed guesthouse at a megachurch in Nigeria's financial capital Lagos has risen to 80 after more bodies were pulled from the rubble, rescuers said today.

item.title: Obama and US lawmakers turn up heat on IS
item.description: Obama has consistently said he will not put US "boots on the ground".

item.title: NKorean reporters using fax to Asian Games file stories
item.description: The Korean Peninsula is still technically in a state of war because there's never been a peace treaty to end the 1950-53 Korean War.

item.title: Texas executes woman convicted of starving 9-year-old
item.description: A woman convicted of the 2004 starving death of a 9-year-old boy was executed on Wednesday by lethal injection at a Texas state prison, authorities said.

item.title: UK mulls joining US air strikes against ISIS
item.description: The British government is preparing the ground to join the United States in launching air strikes against Islamic State in Iraq, but is moving cautiously to ensure it avoids a parliamentary defeat and acts as part of a regional coalition.

item.title: Murder case registered against Nawaz Sharif, ministers
item.description: A murder case has been registered against Pakistan Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, his brother and Punjab chief minister Shahbaz Sharif, three federal ministers and top police officials over the alleged killing of two persons during last month’s clashes between the police and anti-government protesters, police officials said on Wednesday.

item.title: New Qaida wing claims hijacking Pak navy ship
item.description: Al Qaida's South Asia wing has claimed responsibility for hijacking a Pakistani naval ship and trying to use it to fire rockets at US vessels in the Arabian Sea, in the first major assault by the newly created group.

item.title: US House set to approve arms for Syrian rebels
item.description: The Republican-controlled House lined up half-heartedly to give the US military authority to train and arm Syrian rebels on Wednesday as President Barack Obama emphasized that American forces ''do not and will not have a combat mission'' in the struggle against Islamic state militants.
